awd_titl_txt: APS Conferences for Undergraduate Women in Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to the American Physical Society supports the continued growth and improvement of the Conferences for Undergraduate Women in Physics (CUWiP), held annually since 2006. The conferences have two overarching goals: 1) to give undergraduate women the resources, motivation, and confidence to increase their retention in physics and related disciplines; and 2) to increase awareness by undergraduate women in physics of the wide range of career opportunities available to them. Regional conferences are held simultaneously to maximize student attendance by minimizing travel, to increase the excitement of the participants in a joint national venture, and to allow the interactive simulcast of a keynote address. 

The project aims to evaluate networking effectiveness, self-efficacy beliefs, physics identity, and outcome expectations of the participants. Through this research and the project evaluation, there is potential to gain new knowledge about issues facing undergraduate women in physics, as well as measures of the impact that conference activities such as these have on their attendees. The project will advance our understanding of factors that alter the trajectories of female students -- a population that remains underrepresented in physics -- as they pursue undergraduate degrees in physics.

This project is supported jointly by two divisions of NSF's Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate: the Division of Physics and the Division of Materials Research.

por.por_cntn:
APS Conferences for Undergraduate Women in Physics (CUWiP) are three-day regional conferences for undergraduate physics majors. The goals of the conferences are to help undergraduate women and gender minorities continue a career in physics by providing them with an opportunity to experience a professional conference, information about graduate school and professions in physics, and access to other women in physics of all ages with whom they can share experiences, advice, and ideas. 

After several decades of a steady increase in the percentage of physics bachelor's degrees awarded to women  - from less than 5% in the early 1960s to more than 22% in 2002 -  these percentages have been stagnant or declining most years since 2002. Moreover, insufficient numbers of college graduates with STEM degrees are available to meet growing workforce demands*. Recruiting and retaining women and gender minorities into the physics field is a critical component of filling the national need for physicists in the workforce. 

CUWiP aims to improve the representation and experiences of women and gender minorities in physics by providing them with workshops and talks that assist students in navigating their career path and overcoming obstacles within the physics profession, along with ample opportunities for networking and informal mentoring. The conferences have an amplification effect by producing student "ambassadors" for physics at their respective institutions.

The number of participants has been steadily increasing since the first CUWiP in 2006 through 2019, when nearly 2000 people attended the CUWiP in 2019. These numbers, in combination with the total number of Bachelor's in physics awarded to women, indicate that nearly every female undergraduate student in physics will have attended a CUWiP by the time they graduate. CUWiP is unique in its ability to provide an experience that will help every undergraduate women in physics persist in the field. In addition, these conferences provide access to a large number of undergraduate female physicists, thus facilitating research, development, and outreach on other programs that assist in the retention of women in physics. 

Evaluation shows that participants leave the conferences with greater knowledge of job opportunities, career paths, and strategies for achieving these career paths. Additionally, participants show measurable differences in a number of areas that can be related to increased likelihood of persisting in physics. These include a greater sense of community, increased sense of belonging, recognition of themselves as physicists, as well as the formation of peer-peer networks through the conferences. 

 

*NSB 2016: National Science Board (2016). Science and Engineering Indicators. Retrieved from https://www.nsf.gov/nsb/publications/2016/nsb20161.pdf
